column2: Saudi Arabia says it is ready to push an extra 1.3 million barrels a day of oil into the market, to help reverse surging prices.
A group led by the UAE's Etisalat plans to spend \$1bn (544m) on expansion after winning two mobile phone licences in Saudi Arabia.
Network Rail flies in specialist Indian engineers to work on the West Coast Mainline because of a UK skills shortage.
BEDFORD -- Scientists at NitroMed Inc. hope their experimental drugs will cure heart disease someday. But lately their focus has been on more mundane matters.
A Marlborough-based technology company is suing five former employees, including three senior managers, for allegedly conspiring against their employer while working on opening a competing business.
A lawsuit against Gary Winnick, the former chief of Global Crossing, refocuses attention on what Mr. Winnick knew about his company's finances as it imploded.
Russia is again emerging as a superpower - but the reason has less to do with nuclear weapons than with oil.
Kevin B. Rollins, the new chief executive of Dell, talks about Dell's transitory slip in customer service, and why he sees a broader technology recovery taking place.

AP - Meteorologists at North Carolina State University are working on a way to more accurately measure rainfall in small areas.
AP - About half the usual number of loggerhead turtles have nested between North Carolina and Florida this season, and scientists have no explanation for the drop.
AP - A company that unveiled the world's first cloned cat nearly three years ago now says it is ready to start filling orders for cloned pets, a newspaper reported Thursday.

AP - The number of days that beaches closed or posted warnings because of pollution rose sharply in 2003 due to more rainfall, increased monitoring and tougher standards, an environmental group said on Thursday.
AP - Warming water temperatures in the central equatorial Pacific last month may indicate the start of a new El Nino.

Pay for the Washington area's top executives rose significantly last year, reversing the downward trend that set in with the recession in 2001.
Thanks to the SEC, shareholders now get a long-term picture of how their stock is doing, which helps in evaluating executive pay.
For Jeffrey J. Steiner, chairman and chief executive of Fairchild Corp., nearly \$2.5 million in salary last year was just the beginning.
Many of Corporate Washington's executives and board members have side deals with the companies they oversee.
Figuring out how much executives get paid can be like predicting the weather -- an inexact science.
AP - Tiger Woods came up empty in a major again, but he's still the No. 1 ranked player in the world.
AP - Longtime Tennessee Tech women's basketball coach Bill Worrell has agreed to a new three-year contract with the option for three more years, the school announced Sunday.
AP - Brad Ott shot an 8-under 64 on Sunday to win the Nationwide Tour's Price Cutter Charity Championship for his first Nationwide victory.

Braves General Manager John Schuerholz shuffled his deck more than usual this past offseason so doubts were high. Such a challenge makes this season all the sweeter.

The Iranian parliament votes against key parts of a reform plan aimed at opening the economy to foreign investment.
What was the last sound your computer made? It may have emitted a chime when e-mail arrived, or a heraldic swish when you started up Windows.
The jury's still out on whether a computer can ever truly be intelligent, but there's no question that it can have multiple personalities. It's just a matter of software.

More Sudanese refugees flee across the border into Chad following reports of renewed violence in the Darfur region.
Reuters - Venezuelan President Hugo\Chavez has survived a referendum to recall him, according to\results released by electoral authorities on Monday with 94\percent of the vote counted.

Sports car ace Ron Fellows nearly pulled off what arguably would have been the biggest upset in NASCAR history, finishing second after starting last yesterday at Watkins Glen (N.Y.) International.
The US men's and women's eights pulled off huge victories in yesterday's Olympic rowing heats, each setting world bests to advance directly to Sunday's finals.

Liechtenstein's Prince Hans-Adam hands over power to his son and invites the whole nation to a garden party.
